content: I was just wondering if there is anybody who posts here that enjoys camping ,etc. Where is your favorite place to camp? Do you like to go to same place travel to different locals? What was your best/worst trip. I'm sure if you have done any camping you have some good stories. We have been camping as a family for almost 30 years now. Started out in tent, graduated to a bigger tent, then to a small pop-up, then to a larger pop up. Next we moved up to a small travel trailer that had fold out front and back and now we have a 31 foot travel trailer with a slide-out. It let us take the family to some great places that we couldn't afford to go if we had to hotel-it, not to mention some great stories of the trials and tribulations of spending upto 2 weeks , putting up tents and breaking them down the next day to move on. We had a big 12x12 Eureka tent that we could put up in 5 minutes. Everyone had their assigned task in putting it up. Came in handy when you are doing in the rain , in the dark by the light of headlights. Don't miss those days but it is good for a laugh when we sit around reminecsing I have a lot of other stories but would like to here of others.
reply: I was just wondering if there is anybody who posts here that enjoys camping ,etc. Where is your favorite place to camp? Do you like to go to same place travel to different locals? Next we moved up to a small travel trailer that had fold out front and back and now we have a 31 foot travel trailer with a slide-out. It let us take the family to some great places that we couldn't afford to go if we had to hotel-it, not to mention some great stories of the trials and tribulations of spending upto 2 weeks , putting up tents and breaking them down the next day to move on. Came in handy when you are doing in the rain , in the dark by the light of headlights. Don't miss those days but it is good for a laugh when we sit around reminecsing I have a lot of other stories but would like to here of others.
title: RVing , camping , etc.

content: Family vaca was ALWAYS camping!! I rarely stayed in the (above) camper though ~ I used to set up my dad’s old Army canvas pup-tent just off a ways from the site. Luxgery tent; it had a floor, and of course that pesky wooden stake inside, right in the middle!! (I can still remember that canvas smell. . .) This is one of my most favorite secret-spots in P’ay ~ Tioga County along Stonyfork Creek and all it’s beautiful waterfalls; just outside of the “Pennsylvania Grand Canyon”. . . .just spending the day on a sunshine-warmed, flat rock moving with the sunshine to another rock as the (relaxing) day progresses. All the while being mesmerized and hypnotized by the constant sound of the waterfalls. . . from the top pic ~ view looking down on the falls pool; downstream to the left; upstream to the right; and looking up from my ‘sunning spot’ at the sky. Pennsylvania Mountain Laurel ~ picture the woods FILLED with these flowers!! choose joy each day
reply: Family vaca was ALWAYS camping!! I rarely stayed in the (above) camper though ~ I used to set up my dad’s old Army canvas pup-tent just off a ways from the site. content: Nice pics. I camped as a kid in one of those old canvas tents. Had to make sure you didn't touch the sides when it was raining or it would leak. Thank goodness they come with rain flies now. We have never camped in that part of PA before. Have been to Ohiopyle (?) to white wate rafting with the scouts and we have camped as a family at Gettysburg too.
reply: Nice pics. I camped as a kid in one of those old canvas tents. Had to make sure you didn't touch the sides when it was raining or it would leak. Thank goodness they come with rain flies now. We have never camped in that part of PA before. Have been to Ohiopyle (?) to white wate rafting with the scouts and we have camped as a family at Gettysburg too.
title: RVing , camping , etc.

content: Yes ~ do NOT touch the sides of an old canvas tent. . .and don’t hit the pole in the middle of the night or you wake-up with heavy canvas on-top of you!! I’ve been to Ohiopyle. Potter County is quite nice too. So is Warren County. Are you in Pennsylvania? I ask because if you have kids there is a section along Stonyfork Creek with small falls and little natural water slides; that is always a favorite spot for the little guys. I highly recommend the P’ay Grand Canyon if you’ve never seen it. If you like to camp with another campsite 3-feet from yours than forget it, the sites are spread out and Stonyfork Creek Campground has RV hook-ups too. I have more pictures but I have to scan them in. . .it won’t be today but I’ll try to post them for you by this weekend. choose joy each day
reply: Yes ~ do NOT touch the sides of an old canvas tent. . .and don’t hit the pole in the middle of the night or you wake-up with heavy canvas on-top of you!! I’ve been to Ohiopyle. I have more pictures but I have to scan them in. . .it won’t be today but I’ll try to post them for you by this weekend. No , I'm from Kentucky. Won't be camping with any little kids till my grandson (4 months) gets a little older. Actually we are going to the Walnut Valley festival in Winfield , Kansas in Sept and our daughter , son-in-law and grandson will be making the trip with us. Our daughter made her first camping trip when she was 6 months old. It was a bluegrass festival too. I have tons of pics but they have to be scanned too. As far as Ohiopyle , I was a scout leader and we took the troop up there. Seems like we were always just passing thru Pa, except we did go to Gettysburg a couple of times. I do like to hit the Civil War sights. Gettysburg is the crown jewel but have been to Manasas , Fort Donelon in Kentucky, and some others. Hope to swing down and see Shilo in Tenn in September

content: I go camping in a 35' Jayco 5th wheel with 4 slides, central heat and air, satellite tv and surround sound, central vac, etc. etc. I was etting up at one site and the people in a tent next to me said that isn't camping. I just told him that I did my tent thing at Camp DaNang in '65 and '66. He didn't have a clue and strolled away.
reply: I go camping in a 35' Jayco 5th wheel with 4 slides, central heat and air, satellite tv and surround sound, central vac, etc. etc. I was etting up at one site and the people in a tent next to me said that isn't camping. Hey I would have told him camping in camp ground isn't real camping , in a tent or a 5 th wheel so what's the big deal. I enjoyed our days in a tent but I don't miss it. Just call me George Jefferson ..... Movin on up!!

content: We plan to go to a music festival in Kansas in Sept. We then plan to go down to San Antonio for a few days. On the trip back to Ky I would like to detour to Shilo battlefield in Tn. We will pass the Diamond Crater park in Ark were you can dig for diamonds. Has anyone every been there? Is it worth it?

content: Have a friend who goes elk hunting in Colorado, has a GP tent, Civil War surplus, just about kills a pack horse to haul it in. One year it snowed so bad they bagged out and left the tent. The next year it was still there.

content: quote: Originally posted by 18830518: I go camping in a 35' Jayco 5th wheel with 4 slides, central heat and air, satellite tv and surround sound, central vac, etc. etc. I was etting up at one site and the people in a tent next to me said that isn't camping. I just told him that I did my tent thing at Camp DaNang in '65 and '66. He didn't have a clue and strolled away. I know what ya mean, used to think tent camping and sleeping in sleeping bags was the way to go, that was till I started having back problems. Tent camping was not fun anymore! Ya can't beat an RV, especially when a sudden rainstorm in the mountains hits, thats when tent camping tests your patience! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

title: RVing , camping , etc.

content: As a kid, our family camped in the Hoosier National Forest. I saw my first bear and rattlesnake there. My mom was chase by an old naked man. The animals are usually safer than the campers. One spring break I bicycled around the Del-Mar-Va *****ula for five days. I carried a small Eureka tent and sleeping bag with clothes and food. It was a good adventure. Our Cub Scouts camp at Fort DeSoto Park at the southern end of Pinellas County in St. Petersburg every year. Reservations can be made on-line. The park is a great place to kayak, bicycle, and explore the fort and the beach. Watch out for the many unfearless racoons.
reply: As a kid, our family camped in the Hoosier National Forest. I saw my first bear and rattlesnake there. My mom was chase by an old naked man. The animals are usually safer than the campers. One spring break I bicycled around the Del-Mar-Va *****ula for five days. I carried a small Eureka tent and sleeping bag with clothes and food. It was a good adventure. The park is a great place to kayak, bicycle, and explore the fort and the beach. Watch out for the many unfearless racoons.

content: I would like to camp in Florida or at the beach but my wife doesn't like the idea of having to clean sand out of the camper. How is the shade situation at that park. I have seen campgrounds on the outer banks that have absolutely no shade ,and that sun at the beach can be brutal.

content: I love camping. Been awhile... First camping trips were to Northern Minnesota, Canada, Black Hills...back in the early 1970's. Canvas tent. Yup...those were the 'days". I did some camping up in Mammouth Springs Arkansas with my wife and kids, pretty country 20+ years ago. Only vacations..sorta... last few years has been deployments and homecomings to NC. and KY.

title: RVing , camping , etc.

content: Devil's Tower...I climbed that huge 'tooth', and had to get back down...NOT my brightest moment or choice of something to do. I slipped, dropped and destroyed the 35mm camera after all that work of getting to the top to get the awesome photos! I didn't fall, but you can be sure you won't be seeing me clinging to a huge volcanic basalt plug column any more in this lifetime! Gravity works, and oh, so very well! The parks in that area offer excellent camping, trails and wildlife viewing. Stunning...so is Mt. Rushmore and the Badlands of the Dakotas.
reply: Devil's Tower...I climbed that huge 'tooth', and had to get back down...NOT my brightest moment or choice of something to do. If you like to camp with another campsite 3-feet from yours than forget it, the sites are spread out and Stonyfork Creek Campground has RV hook-ups too. I have more pictures but I have to scan them in. . .it won’t be today but I’ll try to post them for you by this weekend. No , I'm from Kentucky. Won't be camping with any little kids till my grandson (4 months) gets a little older. Actually we are going to the Walnut Valley festival in Winfield , Kansas in Sept and our daughter , son-in-law and grandson will be making the trip with us. Our daughter made her first camping trip when she was 6 months old. It was a bluegrass festival too. I have tons of pics but they have to be scanned too. As far as Ohiopyle , I was a scout leader and we took the troop up there. Seems like we were always just passing thru Pa, except we did go to Gettysburg a couple of times. I do like to hit the Civil War sights. Gettysburg is the crown jewel but have been to Manasas , Fort Donelon in Kentucky, and some others. Hope to swing down and see Shilo in Tenn in September
quote: Originally posted by MissU2: Yes ~ do NOT touch the sides of an old canvas tent. . .and don’t hit the pole in the middle of the night or you wake-up with heavy canvas on-top of you!! I’ve been to Ohiopyle. Potter County is quite nice too. So is Warren County. Are you in Pennsylvania? I ask because if you have kids there is a section along Stonyfork Creek with small falls and little natural water slides; that is always a favorite spot for the little guys. I highly recommend the P’ay Grand Canyon if you’ve never seen it. If you like to camp with another campsite 3-feet from yours than forget it, the sites are spread out and Stonyfork Creek Campground has RV hook-ups too. I have more pictures but I have to scan them in. . .it won’t be today but I’ll try to post them for you by this weekend.
reply: No , I'm from Kentucky. Won't be camping with any little kids till my grandson (4 months) gets a little older. Actually we are going to the Walnut Valley festival in Winfield , Kansas in Sept and our daughter , son-in-law and grandson will be making the trip with us. Our daughter made her first camping trip when she was 6 months old. It was a bluegrass festival too. I have tons of pics but they have to be scanned too. As far as Ohiopyle , I was a scout leader and we took the troop up there. Seems like we were always just passing thru Pa, except we did go to Gettysburg a couple of times. I do like to hit the Civil War sights. Gettysburg is the crown jewel but have been to Manasas , Fort Donelon in Kentucky, and some others. Hope to swing down and see Shilo in Tenn in September

content: I go camping in a 35' Jayco 5th wheel with 4 slides, central heat and air, satellite tv and surround sound, central vac, etc. etc. I was etting up at one site and the people in a tent next to me said that isn't camping. I just told him that I did my tent thing at Camp DaNang in '65 and '66. He didn't have a clue and strolled away.
reply: I go camping in a 35' Jayco 5th wheel with 4 slides, central heat and air, satellite tv and surround sound, central vac, etc. etc. I was etting up at one site and the people in a tent next to me said that isn't camping. Just call me George Jefferson ..... Movin on up!!

content: We plan to go to a music festival in Kansas in Sept. We then plan to go down to San Antonio for a few days. On the trip back to Ky I would like to detour to Shilo battlefield in Tn. We will pass the Diamond Crater park in Ark were you can dig for diamonds. Has anyone every been there? Is it worth it?

content: Have a friend who goes elk hunting in Colorado, has a GP tent, Civil War surplus, just about kills a pack horse to haul it in. One year it snowed so bad they bagged out and left the tent. The next year it was still there.

content: quote: Originally posted by 18830518: I go camping in a 35' Jayco 5th wheel with 4 slides, central heat and air, satellite tv and surround sound, central vac, etc. etc. I was etting up at one site and the people in a tent next to me said that isn't camping. I just told him that I did my tent thing at Camp DaNang in '65 and '66. He didn't have a clue and strolled away. I know what ya mean, used to think tent camping and sleeping in sleeping bags was the way to go, that was till I started having back problems. Tent camping was not fun anymore! Ya can't beat an RV, especially when a sudden rainstorm in the mountains hits, thats when tent camping tests your patience! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

title: RVing , camping , etc.

content: As a kid, our family camped in the Hoosier National Forest. I saw my first bear and rattlesnake there. My mom was chase by an old naked man. The animals are usually safer than the campers. One spring break I bicycled around the Del-Mar-Va *****ula for five days. I carried a small Eureka tent and sleeping bag with clothes and food. It was a good adventure. Our Cub Scouts camp at Fort DeSoto Park at the southern end of Pinellas County in St. Petersburg every year. Reservations can be made on-line. The park is a great place to kayak, bicycle, and explore the fort and the beach. Watch out for the many unfearless racoons.
reply: As a kid, our family camped in the Hoosier National Forest. I saw my first bear and rattlesnake there. My mom was chase by an old naked man. The animals are usually safer than the campers. One spring break I bicycled around the Del-Mar-Va *****ula for five days. I carried a small Eureka tent and sleeping bag with clothes and food. It was a good adventure. Our Cub Scouts camp at Fort DeSoto Park at the southern end of Pinellas County in St. Petersburg every year. Reservations can be made on-line. The park is a great place to kayak, bicycle, and explore the fort and the beach. Watch out for the many unfearless racoons.

content: I would like to camp in Florida or at the beach but my wife doesn't like the idea of having to clean sand out of the camper. How is the shade situation at that park. I have seen campgrounds on the outer banks that have absolutely no shade ,and that sun at the beach can be brutal.

content: I love camping. Been awhile... First camping trips were to Northern Minnesota, Canada, Black Hills...back in the early 1970's. Canvas tent. Yup...those were the 'days". I did some camping up in Mammouth Springs Arkansas with my wife and kids, pretty country 20+ years ago. Only vacations..sorta... last few years has been deployments and homecomings to NC. and KY.

I know what ya mean, used to think tent camping and sleeping in sleeping bags was the way to go, that was till I started having back problems. Tent camping was not fun anymore! content: Devil's Tower...I climbed that huge 'tooth', and had to get back down...NOT my brightest moment or choice of something to do. I slipped, dropped and destroyed the 35mm camera after all that work of getting to the top to get the awesome photos! I didn't fall, but you can be sure you won't be seeing me clinging to a huge volcanic basalt plug column any more in this lifetime! Gravity works, and oh, so very well! The parks in that area offer excellent camping, trails and wildlife viewing. Stunning...so is Mt. Rushmore and the Badlands of the Dakotas.
